ThanQ for your response. 

Iam trying to find out if there are any patterns. I agree with you 
that it depends on the degree of oupling between methods. Also, I 
think that the number of unit test cases will determine the effort 
required. 

However, can I come up with an estimate by making some assumptions. 
For eg: the number of parameters required for each method to invoke. 

At the granular level i.e per test case per method, is it possible to 
come up with lines of code (LOC) for JUnit code. If so what are the 
parameters on which the LOC for a particular test case depends on. 
This muct include teh mock classes also. 

Any help is appreciated. 

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
> svaddiparti wrote:
> 
> > Can somebody help me in a methodology for estimating the effort
> > required for developing JUNIT test cases/classes for a complex
> > websphere based application.
> > 
> > appreciate you can share some ideas as to how to go about.
> 
> Are you adding tests to existing code or starting to test-drive new 
> features?
> 
> If you are adding tests to existing code, then the cost of adding 
tests 
> depends directly on the degree of coupling in the application, and 
> without looking at an application, it's tough to say. There is no 
> published generic methodology (like COCOMO) for estimating the 
effort of 
> adding tests that I'm aware of.
> 
> The best I can suggest is to conduct some experiments. See how much 
of 
> the system you can test in a week. This will give you a rough idea, 
at 
> any rate. Even then, it is possible that you'll find a refactoring 
in 
> week three that makes the rest of the system much, much easier to 
test. 
> That is more likely than the reverse -- in other words, the cost of 
> testing a system tends to go down as you cover more of the system 
with 
> tests. (This is a slight simplification, but it's true enough for 
you at 
> this moment.)
> -- 
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Predictable, repeatable, quality delivery
